newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russia may fund extra food imports - Zaveryukha.
newsitem.headline: Russia may fund extra food imports - Zaveryukha.

text.p: Russian Deputy Prime Minister Alexander Zaveryukha, in charge of the harvest, was quoted by Interfax news agency as saying on Monday that the government may allot an extra 200 billion roubles for food imports.

Zaveryukha was quoted as saying the government was considering the issue of extra imports because of Russia's poor production results in the 1996 agricultural year, but he did not mention any specific foods or time periods.
Russian 1996 farm output fell seven percent on 1995's level.
Russia's net grain harvest last year was officially 69.3 million tonnes, the second poor return in a row and one of the worst in about three decades.
Two hundred billion roubles is about $36 million at current exchange rates.
Zaveryukha did not say what government resources, if any, had been used recently to import food.
He said the cabinet was examining the question of signing a resolution authorising the allotment of extra resources for food imports.
The cash-strapped government said last year that it no longer imports grain and said private-sector traders must make up for any slack.
Zaveryukha was quoted as saying domestic prices for sugar and cooking oil had fallen 14.7 percent last year due to strong supplies.
Russian bread-making and macaroni enterprises worked at only 32-42 percent of their capacity in 1996, he said.
